Award.AwardTitle: Assessment for Learning Research Scholars: Capacity Building in Mathematics and Science Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through five assessment scholars for mathematics and science education Gullickson and his CoPIs seek to advance knowledge in K-12 STEM education and assessment practices by building capacity for Assessment for Learning (AfL), improving assessments in K-12 STEM and teacher preparation courses, and providing models for pre-service STEM teacher preparation through enhanced teaching modules. Three goals outlined in the proposal are: (1) faculty from three centers form a learning community, (2) recruit 5 STEM research scholars to conduct research on measurement and evaluation, and (3) expose pre-service teachers to assessment models in their STEM course work.

Their work expands on the existing research in the Assessment for Learning (AfL) program. To accomplish this, the project will advance overlapping learning communities first among faculty, then among STEM Education Research Scholars, ultimately exposing pre-service teachers to assessment models in their STEM coursework and having the scholars study the process. The project is based on a collaboration between three programs at Western Michigan University: The Evaluation Center, Mathematics Education, and the Mallinson Institution for Science Education.

Award Title: Assessment for Learning Research Scholars: Capacity Building in Mathematics and Science Education

 

Outcomes: The Assessment for Learning Research Scholars Project was a joint effort between the mathematics, science, education, and evaluation faculty at Western Michigan University to develop scholars in doctoral programs focused on research on formative assessment. The six-year project supported, or partially supported, nine doctoral students, three of whom completed their doctorates with four additional students choosing to focus their interests in other areas, but contributing to the main research focus of the project. A variety of smaller research activities over the life of the project, including the completed dissertations, focused on raising awareness of formative assessment at the institutional level, developing models for implementing it in university classrooms and amongst STEM and education faculty, and revising STEM-related pre-service methods and content courses to include assessment for learning as a key component of teaching and learning in K-12 and university classrooms. 

 

Findings: Because of the broad nature of research activities investigated in this project, the findings are aligned with those groups most closely involved in the activities. For example, at the institutional level we found little support or even awareness of assessment for learning amongst faculty, courses, or across syllabi for courses at the beginning of the project, but assessment for learning as a teaching/learning principle became an important part of many institution initiatives as a result of interactions of institutional leader groups with our project participants (graduate students and faculty). In terms of institutional doctoral program models, our conception of a student-driven research agenda model proved to be an effective way to initiate doctoral candidates, early in their programs, into the expectations for publishing, research, and academic life. The result was more than 50 publications and presentations on assessment for learning related research with two doctoral students defending three-paper dissertations in the final year of the project. This model represents a non-traditional approach to capacity building that occurred throughout the life of the project. Finally, we interacted with many groups responsible for teaching the pre-service content and methods courses in the WMU teacher education program and found that there is considerable gap between claims about understanding of formative and how those claims would be implemented in a classroom environment. The three completed dissertations in this project describe numerous aspects of this issue and suggested ways in which similar institutions or other researchers interested in formative assessment might address them.

 

Impact/Benefits: This project showed that a project of small size (supporting only a handful of students) can have a positive impact within a large institution. Assessment for learning as a focus for improving education is now a part of this institution’s initiatives affecting STEM education in general and more specifically those involving teacher education.
